factoid: The narrator had received and given the orders for the next day's battle.
The narrator had nothing more to do after giving the orders.
The narrator's thoughts were the simplest, clearest, and therefore most terrible.
The narrator's thoughts gave him no peace.
The narrator knew that tomorrow's battle would be the most terrible of all he had taken part in.
The narrator considered the possibility of death for the first time in his life.
The narrator considered death in relation to himself and his own soul.
The narrator saw death as vivid, plain, terrible, and almost certain.
The narrator's perception illuminated all that had previously tormented and preoccupied him with a cold white light.
The narrator saw all life as magic-lantern pictures he had gazed at by artificial light through a glass.
The narrator saw those badly daubed pictures in clear daylight without a glass.
The narrator said, 'Yes, yes! There they are, those false images that agitated, enraptured, and tormented me.'
The narrator reviewed the principal pictures of the magic lantern of life.
The narrator regarded those pictures now in the cold white daylight of the narrator's clear perception of death.
The narrator saw the pictures as rudely painted figures that once seemed splendid and mysterious.
The narrator said, 'Glory, the good of society, love of a woman, the Fatherland itself—how important these pictures appeared to me, with what profound meaning they seemed to be filled!'
The narrator said, 'And it is all so simple, pale, and crude in the cold white light of this morning which I feel is dawning for me.'
The narrator's three great sorrows were love for a woman, the narrator's father's death, and the French invasion that overran half Russia.
The narrator loved a little girl who seemed to him brimming over with mystic forces.
The narrator made romantic plans of love and happiness with the girl.
The narrator believed in an ideal love that would keep the girl faithful for the whole year of the narrator's absence.
The narrator compared the girl to a gentle dove in a fable that would pine apart from the narrator.
The narrator said the love was simple and horrible.
The narrator's father built Bald Hills.
The narrator's father thought Bald Hills was the narrator's father's land, the narrator's father's air, and the narrator's father's peasants.
Napoleon came and swept the narrator's father aside, unconscious of the narrator's father's existence.
Napoleon brushed the narrator's father's life aside as if brushing a chip from his path.
Napoleon's action caused the narrator's father's Bald Hills and the narrator's father's whole life to fall to pieces.
Princess Mary said the narrator's father's death was a trial sent from above.

Princess Mary asked, 'What is the trial for, when the narrator's father is not here and will never return? He is not here! For whom then is the trial intended? The Fatherland, the destruction of Moscow!'

The narrator said, 'And tomorrow I shall be killed, perhaps not even by a Frenchman but by one of our own men, by a soldier discharging a musket close to my ear as one of them did yesterday, and the French will come and take me by head and heels and fling me into a hole that I may not stink under their noses, and new conditions of life will arise, which will seem quite ordinary to others and about which I shall know nothing. I shall not exist.'
The narrator looked at the row of birches shining in the sunshine, with their motionless green and yellow foliage and white bark.
The narrator thought, 'To die... to be killed tomorrow... That I should not exist... That all this should still be, but no me.'
The narrator observed that the birches with their light and shade, the curly clouds, the smoke of the campfires, and all that was around him changed and seemed terrible and menacing.
A cold shiver ran down the narrator's spine.
The narrator rose quickly, went out of the shed, and began to walk about.
After the narrator had returned, voices were heard outside the shed.
The narrator cried, 'Who's that?'

The red-nosed Captain Timókhin, formerly Dólokhov's squadron commander, but now a battalion commander due to lack of officers, shyly entered the shed followed by an adjutant and the regimental paymaster.
Prince Andrew rose hastily, listened to the business they had come about, gave them some further instructions, and was about to dismiss them when he heard a familiar, lisping voice behind the shed.
The voice said, 'Devil take it!' The voice belonged to a man stumbling over something.
